economic_context.details: Multiple debt disputes including 11 francs expenses from Bastien Begel, 2 francs debt to Georgeon Poirat, unpaid wheat loan to Jannon veuve Colas Jean Belat, unpaid taxes leading to cauldron seizure. Theft accusations including stolen ploughshare, attempted hay theft, stolen sheet. General reputation for 'abus que tromperie' (abuses and deceptions). Accused was condemned to pay 100 écus fine plus costs and restitution for animal theft. Unable to pay debts or fine, fled prison when no-one worked for his release. Trial and execution costs were 45 francs.

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a particularly detailed trial record with 20 witnesses providing extensive testimony. The accused had a long family history of witchcraft accusations spanning three generations (grandmother, mother, siblings, and daughter). The trial is notable for ending in suicide rather than execution or torture. The accused was already imprisoned for theft when witchcraft charges were added. Strong pattern of quarrel-threat-harm sequence in witness testimony. Economic disputes and reputation for fraud feature prominently alongside witchcraft accusations. The accused's escape from prison and subsequent recapture added complexity to the case. His body was posthumously executed (hung face down from forked tree) and goods confiscated.
